entry.title: TechEd Recap: Creating AI-Enhanced UX for Your Own Applications with SAP Design System
entry.content:
By Sophia Levens and Thomas Reiss

We were thrilled to speak at this year’s TechEd conference in Berlin on how the SAP Design System is powering the next generation of AI-led product design. Our Deep Dive talk entitled “Creating AI-enhanced UX for your own applications with SAP Design System” focused on three key areas: an introduction into the SAP Design System, new AI patterns for the design system and SAPUI5, and our AI-powered tools for our UI technologies. We then closed the session with an overview of the resources available to designers and developers today.

Below we’ll share a recap of the major points and announcements from the session. You can also watch the recorded session here.

 

Introduction to the SAP Design System

The overall mission of the SAP Design System is to unify and advance the SAP user experience. We achieve this in two ways:

  • Unify: The SAP Design System serves as the central hub of ready-to-use assets, guidance and standards for building delightful experiences that are consistent across the SAP portfolio. This is how we directly contribute to SAP’s Suite-First strategy.
  • Advance: The SAP Design System provides the essential patterns and tools to embed transformative AI experiences across all products and touchpoints. This is how we directly contribute to the AI-First goal.

What exactly is a design system?

In order to deliver consistent and inclusive UX, the SAP Design System is made up of the following elements:

  1. Design Language: The most foundational elements that go into any brand. For example, color, type, iconography, illustrations, etc.
  2. Components: The building blocks for creating user interfaces, like buttons, drop down menus, or input fields.
  3. Patterns: Covers a use case or user flow, things like exporting data to PDF or a search workflow.
  4. Floorplans: A full UI layout. Typically, floorplans are a complete page or even span several pages.

The SAP Design System extends across SAP. It helps to unify all touchpoints across the SAP brand including our products, our digital experiences like sap.com, and other marketing and communications including interactive events like TechEd. And because the system is open source, our customers can also use the design system to build upon and customize our products and platforms.

What UI technologies are supported with the SAP Design System?

For each element in the SAP Design System, we build reusable components in code that developers can leverage to accelerate their workflow. There are two ways to leverage SAP technologies—via “floorplans and building blocks” or “freestyle”.

  • Build “freestyle” with SAPUI5 and SAP Web Components: Freestyle allows you full control of every element on the screen.
  • Use “floorplans and building blocks” with SAP Fiori Elements: This lets you accelerate development when the desired app or workflow is close to one of the out-of-the box floorplans or building blocks.

Because both of these choices are based on SAPUI5, you don’t have to choose one or the other, you can mix both ways of developing leveraging each when needed.

 

New AI Patterns for the SAP Design System and SAPUI5

SAP is proud to offer AI components and patterns for web and mobile. We’re investing in making it easy to design and build great AI experiences that are responsible, flexible, and work across ecosystems. Our AI experience principles are built on the following six pillars: design for clarity, earn trust, give control, design fairly, boost flow, fail-safe.

Find the latest AI patterns and components:

  • SAP Design System portal
  • SAP Web UI Kit
  • SAP Fiori for iOS UI Kit
  • SAP Fiori for Android UI Kit
  • UI5 Web Components

Our AI components and patterns have gone through the process of reviews and testing by our experts in user assistance, accessibility, user research, and are compliant with SAP’s legal and ethical AI standards. These are patterns you and your users can trust.

 

Using our AI-powered UI Technologies to Help You Build Faster

We have introduced powerful AI tools to help you build UIs and applications faster.

SAP Joule for Developers is a collection of embedded AI capabilities for SAP Build as well as for ABAP, delivered through Joule, that accelerates development of apps and extensions, reduces costs, and improves developer proficiency.

The SAP Fiori tools project accelerator, which can be started from Joule in SAP Build Code, enables developers to create CAP-based (Cloud Application Programming model based) SAP Fiori elements applications directly from an image of the intended outcome. These images can be high fidelity Figma models, lower fidelity screenshots or a sketch on paper. Simply upload the image and use AI to generate the data models, services and the UI. Find out more in this blog post: From idea to app: using AI-powered Project Accelerator to develop SAP Fiori apps.

 Generate a complete CAP-based application from a sketch with SAP Fiori tools project accelerator: data models, services and UI.

Recently, we have gone even further and introduced MCP servers for freestyle SAPUI5 development as well as for developing with SAP Fiori elements and the associated building blocks. These open-source Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers equip developers with valuable support by providing AI agents with comprehensive UI5 and SAP Fiori elements knowledge, including best practices and project-aware context information.

Read about the new MCP servers in these blog posts:

  • UI5 MCP Server.
  • MCP Server for SAP Fiori.

Key Takeaways

This deep dive session gave an overview of how customers and partners can create AI-enhanced UX for their own applications with the SAP Design System and SAP’s UI technologies. Find everything you need to get started designing and developing:

  • Get started with the SAP Design System portal.
  • Use SAP's UI kits with the new AI patterns.
  • Use SAPUI5.

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Foundational SAP Notes for SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
This blog post lists the main SAP Notes and software components for SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA 2025. 
This collection is provided as an aid to those customers installing or upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2025 Cloud Private edition or SAP S/4HANA 2025 On-Premise.

Information is current for the initial shipment stack (ISS) of SAP S/4HANA 2025.

IMPORTANT: Many customers often ask whether they should wait for FPS1 before starting their SAP S/4HANA 2025 projects. To help clarify this, the SAP S/4HANA Regional Implementation Group (RIG) has published a dedicated blog:
Should you wait until FPS1 is available before implementing or upgrading to SAP S/4HANA 2025?

The blog explains that SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS00 is a mature and stable release, already shipping with the long-term maintenance version SAPUI5 1.136, so customers can confidently begin their implementations from day one without waiting for FPS1.

You can find additional information on the major changes for SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA 2025 in blog posts:

    • SAP User Experience Update: What’s New for SAP S/4HANA 2025 (Private Cloud and On-Premise)

You can find additional information on the major changes for SAP Fiori Frontend Server in blog post:

    • SAP Fiori deployment options and SAP Fiori front-end server strategy - UPDATE 2025

IMPORTANT: Especially please note the statements in the above blog post around Strategy and future direction for SAP Fiori front-end server. Especially:

SAP Fiori front-end server 2025 for SAP S/4HANA (SAP FES 2025) :

  • has the same deployment recommendations as the predecessor versions (embedded or standalone FES server for SAP S/4HANA systems, hub deployment for Business Suite).
  • The end of maintenance of SAP FES 2025 is aligned with the maintenance period of SAP S/4HANA 2025. See also SAP note 3574267 - SAP Fiori front-end server 2025 for SAP S/4HANA.

You can find additional information on the major changes for the ABAP Platform in blog post:

    • ABAP Platform - major changes - COMING SOON!

Upgrading from a lower release of SAP S/4HANA:

  • Make sure you are aware of the major shifts in SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA. Refer to: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Upgrade Faster – Major shifts in SAP Fiori implementation

Planning to go Clean Core or use SAP Business AI with SAP S/4HANA 2025:

Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Minimum UX you need for SAP Business AI and Clean Core

Important changes:

New apps for SAP S/4HANA 2025:

The new apps are already available in the SAP Fiori apps reference library.

Particularly useful new apps are:

  • F8438 Manage News
  • F7763 Cost Centers Review Booklet
  • F8226 HR Admin Processes 
  • F7651 Manage Payment Orders
  • and many new apps for MDG, Utilities, HCM for SAP S/4HANA, Group Reporting, Public Services, Transportation Management, and many more. 

There are also significant improvements in extending apps with Adapt UI including:

  • Adapt UI tour of the major features and options
  • What's New tour of Adapt UI 
  • New capabilities in changing table behaviors such as scrolling behaviour, text/id arrangements and many more. 

Hint: The library is regularly updated every couple of weeks with any changes.

When using the What's New Viewer - SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition  filter on solution area ABAP Platform, valid as of release 2025, and look for solution capability SAP Fiori launchpad

Particularly useful new tools are:

  • Launchpad Content Aggregator for Roles now includes both content and layouts - refer to transaction /UI2/FLPCA
  • Launchpad Content Aggregator for User - refer to transaction /UI2/FLPCA_USER
  • You can set launchpad configuration parameters (client settings) for roles - refer to transaction /UI2/FLP_PROF_CONF
  • You can access an Administrator view of App Support, called the App Inspector.

Patching for Kernel

Find the current minor patch levels by checking the SAP Note 2083594 – SAP Kernel Versions and SAP Kernel Patch Levels . This includes the link to the latest patch note in the format: SAP Kernel <major version> Patch Level <patch level number>

entry.title: Handling $filter,$search and $orderby in SAP CAP when consuming External REST APIs
entry.content:
Introduction

When building applications with the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), a very common real-world scenario is:

  • Your CAP service acts as a proxy
  • Data is fetched from an external REST API
  • The external API does not support OData

But your Fiori/UI5 frontend still sends OData queries like: 

$filter=country eq 'IN'&$search=Bangalore&$orderby=name desc

This blog explains how to handle OData query options like $filter, $search, and $orderby in SAP CAP Node.js when your service consumes a non-OData external REST API.

Here is a lightweight JavaScript utility (handleOData.js) that:

  • Interprets CAP’s query structure (req.query.SELECT)
  • Applies filtering logic directly on API responses
  • Adds full-text search capability
  • Supports dynamic sorting based on $orderby

With this approach, your Fiori/UI applications can continue using rich OData queries without any dependency on the external API.

This solution is ideal for building CAP-based proxy services on SAP BTP that integrate with legacy or third-party REST systems.

Problem Statement : 

Consider this scenario: Your frontend sends

GET /odata/v4/srv/DemandAreas?$filter=country eq 'IN'&$orderby=name asc

But your backend actually calls ,   

GET https://external.api/demandAreas

The external API:

  • Does not support $filter
  • Does not support $search
  • Does not support $orderby

Yet you still want your frontend to fully leverage OData features.

So how do we bridge this gap?

Architecture Overview:

Solution Overview: 

Utility file , handleOData.js exposes three main functions:

module.exports = { handleFilter, handleSearch, handleSort }

Each function handles a specific OData concept.

1. Handling $filter

CAP provides filters in a structured format (req.query.SELECT.where).

This utility interprets this structure and evaluates it against each result record.

Core logic idea:

function handleFilter(filters, item) {
  const stack = [];

  const applyComparison = (field, op, value) => {
    const fieldValue = item[field];

    switch (op) {
      case '=': return fieldValue == value;
      case '!=': return fieldValue != value;
      case '>': return fieldValue > value;
      case '>=': return fieldValue >= value;
      case '<': return fieldValue < value;
      case '<=': return fieldValue <= value;
      default: return false;
    }
  };

  // Logic continues to resolve AND / OR conditions}

This supports:

  • eq, ne, gt, ge, lt, le
  • Logical operations: AND, OR
  • Nested conditions

2. Handling $search

CAP exposes the search phrase via req.query.SELECT.search. The utility applies search across properties of each record.

Simplified logic:

function handleSearch(searchTerm, data) {
  return data.filter(item =>
    Object.values(item).some(val =>
      String(val).toLowerCase().includes(searchTerm.toLowerCase())
    )
  );
}

This allows our Fiori/UI app to use for example , $search=Bangalore

Even if the external API has no search support at all.

3. Handling $orderby

Ordering is handled using CAP’s orderBy structure.

Logic overview:

function handleSort(req, result) {
  const [orderClause] = req.query.SELECT.orderBy;
  const field = orderClause.ref[0];
  const dir = orderClause.sort === 'desc' ? -1 : 1;

  return [...result].sort((a, b) =>
    a[field] > b[field] ? 1 * dir : -1 * dir
  );
}

Supported:

  • $orderby=name asc
  • $orderby=createdAt desc

CAP Service Integration Example

Below is how you can plug this into your service implementation file:

const { handleFilter, handleSearch, handleSort } = require('./code/handleOData');
module.exports = (srv) => {

  srv.on('READ', 'DemandAreas', async (req) => {

    // 1. Call external REST APIlet data = await fetchExternalData();

    // 2. Apply $filterif (req.query.SELECT.where) {
      data = data.filter(item => handleFilter(req.query.SELECT.where, item));
    }

    // 3. Apply $searchif (req.query.SELECT.search) {
      data = handleSearch(req.query.SELECT.search, data);
    }

    // 4. Apply $orderbyif (req.query.SELECT.orderBy) {
      data = handleSort(req, data);
    }

    return data;
  });
};

Benefits of this Approach

  • Clean separation between CAP and external REST API
  • Full OData filtering support for Fiori/UI apps
  • No dependency on the external service supporting OData
  • Plug-and-play in any Node.js CAP project
  • Easy to extend with more operators

Conclusion:

This utility helps bridge the gap between OData-driven applications and non-OData REST services, while keeping our CAP service clean and the UI fully functional. If you’re building similar integrations, I hope this helps accelerate your work.

entry.title: Design Fiori Apps in Figma
entry.content:
Why SAP Fiori is the Future

With SAP Fiori, users not only get more modern applications but can also use apps via mobile devices like tablets or smartphones.

The SAP world is gradually shifting towards Fiori. Old technologies like SAP GUI or WDA are becoming things of the past, being replaced by the modern look and feel of Fiori interfaces.

Users benefit from a significantly better user experience. The individual apps are more consistent and uniform, which supports new users or occasional users in working smoothly. A fact that shouldn’t be underestimated is that 80% of all users in the Fiori environment use apps only occasionally (approx. 2 hours/week) and therefore don't know every app inside out.

But power users also benefit from Fiori apps and the new features they bring. SAP Fiori paves the way for AI - for instance, SAP’s new AI assistant “Joule” can be used directly within Fiori apps.

So, SAP Fiori opens up numerous potentials - for a modern look and feel, but also for utilizing the numerous standard applications that SAP provides in the Fiori Apps Library.

Designing Your Own Fiori Apps is the Right Way to Go!

Creating screen designs for SAP Fiori apps makes it possible to gather feedback from users at an early stage.

However, if the SAP standard doesn't fit your specific requirements, the best path is to design and develop your own Fiori apps. This way, you can create the best possible solution for your users and maintain full control over the associated processes and workflows.

Ideally, you can involve Key Users directly in the design of new Fiori apps. In the end, this ensures high user acceptance and happy users.

Designing Fiori Apps with Figma

Figma is a very well-known prototyping tool that UX designers typically use to create screendesigns and click dummies for new apps and websites. While the tool isn't specifically geared only towards SAP Fiori, it works excellently for designing Fiori apps when combined with the templates provided by SAP (the SAP Fiori Design Stencils).

It pays off to design Fiori apps with a tool like Figma before they go into development. This makes the planned solution tangible before investing the huge effort that comes with technical development. Future users can give their feedback based on screendesigns, allowing the Fiori app to be optimized directly. This guarantees an optimal solution without having to make many expensive adjustments to the productive app later on.

Designing Fiori apps in Figma specifically means that we create screendesigns. Such screendesigns show in true-to-life detail how the Fiori app will actually look in the end. The differences compared to the final development are minimal.

We can also easily arrange the Fiori screendesigns in Figma into click prototypes. This allows interactions and user flows (e.g., opening dialogs or navigating between screens) to be demonstrated clearly.

Note: Fiori apps can be designed in great detail in Figma. The final screendesigns are often indistinguishable from the implementation. Interactions like navigation between screens or dialogs can also be implemented easily in Figma.

Tutorial: How You Can Design Fiori Apps with Figma

1. Install Figma

Download page of the Figma desktop client.

Figma is the best tool for designing Fiori apps - precisely because SAP officially supports it by providing design templates. Figma can be used both in the browser and as an installed version.

Personally, I would recommend installing Figma, as the performance is often slightly better than in the browser. You can find the download on the official website:

In any case, you will need a free Figma account, which you should create now.

2. Install SAP Fiori Fonts

SAP page for downloading the required fonts "72" and "Business Icon Font".

To work seamlessly with the Fiori templates in Figma, you need to quickly install two fonts on your PC.

First is the SAP font "72", which you can download from SAP here:

And second is the "Business Icon" font, which you can download from SAP here:

Unzip both .zip files and then install the fonts.

3. Open Fiori Templates in Figma (SAP S/4HANA Web UI Kit)

Figma page of the SAP S/4HANA WEB UI Kit – the official Fiori design templates from SAP for use in Figma.

To start creating designs for Fiori apps in Figma, it is necessary to open the official templates from SAP. These templates contain all the UI elements that exist in Fiori. From buttons, tables, or selection fields to complete pages and Fiori floorplans, such as the List Report or the Object Page, you will find everything you need here to design Fiori apps.

SAP provides different templates depending on whether you are creating a Fiori app for the Web, Android, or iOS. However, in 90% of cases, you will be designing your own Fiori apps for your SAP S/4HANA. Therefore, you can find the suitable templates here:

Note: SAP updates and expands this template regularly. Therefore, it is worth re-importing the Fiori templates every few months!

4. Overview of Fiori Templates in Figma

View of Figma with the opened page "List Report" from the "SAP S/4HANA Web UI Kit".

Once you have opened the Web UI Kit in Figma, you should see a long list of "Pages" in the left area of Figma. In these many pages, you will find the individual UI elements and templates of SAP Fiori that you can now use.

Take a few moments to get an overview. For example, on the "Buttons" page, we find all the numerous button types of Fiori. Under "Responsive Table," you will find something more complex: the tables you can use in your Fiori apps. And if you scroll down very far, you will find layout templates for all Fiori Elements floorplans under "List Report," for example.

And exactly this template is what we will grab in the next step!

Design Your First Fiori App with Fiori Elements Templates

From my experience as a Fiori UX Designer, 90% of all Fiori apps are implemented using Fiori Elements. Fiori Elements is a way to accelerate the development (and design) of custom Fiori apps by using ready-made templates ("floorplans"). If you've ever seen a Fiori app, you've most likely seen such a floorplan.

For our first Fiori app, we will also use such a floorplan as a foundation to speed up the design process while building a solid solution.

The Idea for Our Fictional Fiori App

Sketch of our planned Fiori app.

Our Fiori app should fulfill the following fictional use case:

  • On an overview: List all invoices my company has sent to customers and make them filterable.

  • On a detail view: Provide comprehensive information regarding a specific invoice.

From this use case, it follows that we need two screendesigns: the overview and the detail view. Ideally, we can use two classic Fiori Elements floorplans here: the List Report (for the overview) and the Object Page (for the detail view).

Designing a List Report in Figma

Copying the "List Report" into a new Figma file as a starting point for our Fiori app.

So let's start with the List Report. To do this, we open the previously opened Fiori templates in Figma again and go to the "List Report" page. There, we copy the layer "XL 1440px" on the left side and paste it into a new Figma file.

We can create a new Figma file by clicking on the small Figma icon in the top left -> File -> New Design File. In the new design file, you then paste the List Report template with Ctrl + V!

What you see now is an existing template for a List Report - the perfect starting point for our design. This template contains sample data that doesn't fit our fictional Fiori app - but we can change that quite easily.

Adjusting Texts

Adjusting texts in the "List Report". Here we are changing the column headers as an example – in principle, all texts can be adjusted as desired!

If you press "T" and then click on an existing text with the mouse cursor, you can change it. With this, you can now adjust, for example, filter names, column headers, or texts in the tables and buttons.

Note: If changing a text is not possible, it might be that the required fonts are not installed. If changes are not possible despite installed fonts, I recommend using the Figma desktop client.

Deleting UI Elements

Deleting unneeded elements is done by selecting and pressing the "Delete" key. In this example, I am deleting some unneeded filters from the header.

If you no longer need elements, you can delete them. To do this, you have to click on the corresponding element and then press "Delete".

 

Note: You might have to click on an element multiple times to select it, as you are essentially clicking through the hierarchy in the design. This way, you can now delete filters, buttons, or table rows. If you make a mistake, you can undo it with Ctrl + Z.

Adapting UI Elements

Almost every Fiori UI element can be customized. To do this, you can select an element and see the associated settings options in the panel on the right side. In the example, I am changing the button style of the "Create" button.

Many UI elements can also be customized. For example, if you select the "Create" button, you will see properties on the right side that you can change. If you change the Type to "Primary", for instance, the button becomes a primary button and gets a blue background. You can adjust the look and feel of very many UI elements according to your wishes. Feel free to try out all options - you can't do anything wrong! 😉

You can now also select the table ("Responsive Table") in the design and choose the value "Columns" for the "Structure" property. This ensures that you can adjust (delete or add) the individual columns of the table more easily.

For Our Example Fiori App

In our example, I am now adjusting the texts in the filters and the table according to the use case. I am removing unneeded filters and columns in the table. The end result is our List Report of the invoices!

Our final screen design for the overview page of our fictional Fiori app. Based on the floorplan, filters, columns, and buttons, for example, were adapted.

Designing an Object Page in Figma

Adapting the "Object Page" floorplan in Figma. Here I am removing some unneeded elements and adjusting the text of the title.

Now we want to create the detail page for a single invoice for our fictional Fiori app. To do this, we go back to the Fiori templates and switch to the "Object Page". Here we now see different variations of the Object Page for different screen sizes.

We simply click on the Object Page variant that is at the very top left, copy it again to the clipboard, and paste it into our Figma design where we have also placed the List Report.

Similar to the List Report, we can adapt the individual UI elements of the Object Page as we please - meaning we can: change texts, adapt or remove elements.

Adapting the Floorplan for Our Example Fiori App

Our detail page of an invoice, fully designed in Figma.

In our example, we primarily remove some UI elements that we don't need - for example, the graphic and the popover at the top left. We adjust texts and tables so that it fits our use case.

Prototyping: Linking the List Report and Object Page

After switching to "Prototype" mode, navigation from the overview page to the detail page can be implemented via drag-and-drop.

We have now designed two very simple views for our Fiori app. Now we can go a step further and insert interactions.

For this example, we will add navigation from the List Report page to the Object Page, as this is an integral part of our planned app.

To do this, we first have to switch to "Prototype" mode - we do this by clicking on the "Prototype" tab in the top right panel.

Then we select the arrow in the last column of the table from the List Report and drag-and-drop an arrow onto the Object Page.

Subsequently, we can also test the interaction in presentation mode. To do this, we select the List Report and click on the Play button at the top right. This opens a new tab.

If we have done everything correctly, we can now navigate to the Obect Page by clicking on the arrow in the List Report table!

Opening presentation mode by selecting the "Overview Page" and clicking the "Play" button at the top right.

Congratulations - You Have Designed Your First Fiori App!

In our example, we have now created two simple screendesigns based on existing templates ("floorplans") and linked them via prototyping.

If you have made it this far: Congratulations - you have successfully designed your first Fiori app! 🙂

Deeper Adjustments of Floorplans and Designing Complex Fiori Apps

It is often necessary and useful to expand the designs even further. In principle, every aspect of such a screendesign can be adapted and expanded in Figma. New UI elements can be added, the layouting adjusted, or interactions such as opening dialogs and navigation up to concrete features can be realized in Figma.

The implementation possibilities have no limits here. If none of the Fiori Elements floorplans fit your use case, you can also design a Fiori Freestyle App in Figma.

However, all of this requires advanced skills and techniques in handling Figma for Fiori, which I deliberately do not want to include in this beginner's guide, as they often do not achieve the desired goal without direct guidance from an expert.

Conclusion & Key Takeaways

Designing Fiori apps doesn't have to be complicated. As we have seen, using Figma combined with the official SAP templates bridges the gap between complex technical requirements and a user-friendly interface.

Here are the key takeaways from this guide:

  • User Experience First: Moving to Fiori ensures a consistent, modern, and intuitive experience for your users.

  • Visualize Before You Build: Prototyping in Figma makes the solution tangible. It allows you to gather feedback from key users early, preventing expensive changes during the actual development phase.

  • Leverage Standards: You don't need to reinvent the wheel. Using Fiori Elements floorplans (like the List Report and Object Page) speeds up the design process significantly.

  • Official Resources: The SAP S/4HANA Web UI Kit in Figma provides you with everything you need to create professional and accurate designs.

Let's connect!

Do you need help or support using Figma for creating Fiori screendesigns? Or do you have specific questions about the workflow?

Feel free to send me a message or simply write a comment below this post. I am curious to hear about your experiences with designing Fiori apps!

A special thank you: Finally, I want to send a big thank you to the SAP Design Team for providing and regularly maintaining these Fiori templates for Figma. They are a massive help for the entire ecosystem and make our work as designers much easier.

Happy Designing!

entry.title: How to display Microsoft documents along with PDF and Images in SAP UI5 application
entry.content:
Overview:

Displaying Microsoft document type DOCX, PPT, XSLX etc. along with PDF and Image in SAP UI5/Fiori Application.

Business Requirement:

In one of my project, I have requirement where customer want to display all the attachments like docx, pdf, or pptx etc. inside fiori application. So, the user does not need to switch to different application on the system to view documents.

By default, Fiori provides preview capabilities for PDFs and images, but it does not support Microsoft file formats. But Since the customer needs to preview these file types directly inside the Fiori app, I explored alternatives and determined that the Apryse WebViewer SDK is capable of meeting this requirement

Note: This has additional licensing which customer procured in our case. There are few other libraries which you can utilize based on your requirement.

Step by Step Implementation:

  1. Create an MTA project and add a Fiori application to it.
  2. Now, we need to set up the webviewer sdk in the project. Open terminal from fiori application directory and run command npm i @pdftron/webviewer.
  3. Create a lib folder inside webapp and copy the core, ui, webviewer.min.js from node_modules/@pdftron/webviewer/public.

4. For our project, We created html div container which will display the document inside webviewer when user clicks on LoadDocument button.

5. In Controller, on onLoadDocumentPress, we will initialize and load webviewer like shown in below image

6. Open the terminal and run the command npm run start .

 

Note: License would be required to remove the watermark from the document.

Summary:

WebViewer supports viewing multiple document types, such as PDF, PPTX, and DOCX. In the example above, the document is rendered by converting a Base64-encoded string into a blob, but WebViewer also allows loading documents directly using a file path.

For more information, you can refer following link

Detailed code is available on github repo.

entry.title: Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
entry.content:
In our previous posts, we explored individual building blocks, their sophisticated capabilities, and how they come together in standard floorplans. We also learned how to extend these standard floorplans when needed. But what happens when your business requirements demand a layout that doesn't match any standard floorplan? The SAP Fiori development portal has you covered. In this post, we'll show you how to build a completely custom page layout while leveraging SAP Fiori elements building blocks to maintain enterprise-grade functionality.

When to Choose Custom Pages

Before we dive into creating custom pages, let's be clear about the decision path. If your UI requirements fit one of the existing standard floorplans (List Report, Object Page, Analytical List Page, Overview Page, or Worklist), you should absolutely use them. Standard floorplans offer:

  • Reduced development and maintenance costs
  • Automatic UI consistency across your application landscape
  • Built-in enterprise features that would take months to develop from scratch
  • Future-proof compatibility with SAP Fiori elements updates

However, when you need a special layout - like a wizard, shopping cart, or any non-standard UI pattern - you're not blocked. You can implement your custom layout while using as many SAP Fiori elements building blocks as possible to retain the benefits of the framework.

Exploring Custom Pages in the Portal

The SAP Fiori development portal's Custom Page  chapter provides comprehensive guidance for building custom layouts. Let's explore its key sections:

  • Overview - Shows a simple custom page demonstrating how building blocks integrate into custom layouts
  • Building Blocks Usage - Explains how to use SAP Fiori elements building blocks in existing UI5 freestyle applications, bridging the gap between traditional UI5 development and the SAP Fiori elements approach
  • Custom Root View - Demonstrates how to create and register custom root views when the standard options (FullScreen and Flexible Column Layout) don't meet your needs
  • Draft Handling - Shows how to leverage the Draft controller extension in your custom pages for seamless draft management

Fiori Development Portal: Custom page sample

These sections provide the foundation for understanding custom page development. Now let's put this knowledge into practice with a real-world example.

Building a Wizard: A Step-by-Step Journey

Let's create a wizard for travel request creation - a floorplan currently not available as a standard in SAP Fiori elements. We'll build this step by step, just as you would when developing your own custom page. The beauty of the portal is that you can experiment with code changes - auto-run is enabled by default, automatically refreshing the preview when you make simple changes. For more complex modifications, you can disable auto-run and manually click the "Run" button to update the sample when you're ready.

Step 1: Setting Up the Wizard Structure

Navigate to the Custom Pages Overview section in the portal. Click "Show Code" to open the code editor. We'll transform this simple page into a wizard.

First, let's add the wizard structure without any content in the steps. Replace the content of the CustomPageSample view with:

<mvc:View
	id="application-product"
	height="100%"
	controllerName="sap.fe.core.fpmExplorer.customPage.CustomPageSample"
	xmlns="sap.m"
	xmlns:mvc="sap.ui.core.mvc"
	xmlns:macros="sap.fe.macros"
>
	<macros:Page title="Create New Travel Request" class="sapUiContentPadding">
		<Wizard
			id="travelWizard"
			enableBranching="false"
			class="sapUiResponsivePadding--header sapUiResponsivePadding--content"
		>
			<WizardStep
				id="travelDataStep"
				title="Travel Information"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>

			<WizardStep
				id="approvalDataStep"
				title="Budget and Approval"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>

			<WizardStep
				id="bookingsStep"
				title="Bookings"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>

			<WizardStep
				id="reviewStep"
				title="Submit Travel Request"
				validated="true"
			>
				<!-- We'll add content here -->
			</WizardStep>
		</Wizard>
	</macros:Page>
</mvc:View>

Now update the controller to support the wizard functionality. In the controller code editor, replace the CustomPageSample controller with:

import PageController from "sap/fe/core/PageController";
import MessageBox from "sap/m/MessageBox";
import type Context from "sap/ui/model/odata/v4/Context";

/**
 * Controller for the custom travel request wizard page.
 */
export default class CustomPageSampleController extends PageController {
	/**
	 * Creates a new travel request draft context and binds it to the view before rendering.
	 */
	public onBeforeRendering(): void {
		const view = this.getView();

		try {
			const model = view.getModel();

			// Create list binding and create a draft context
			const listBinding = model.bindList("/Travel");
			const wizardContext = listBinding.create({
				CurrencyCode_code: "EUR",
				BookingFee: 0,
				TotalPrice: 0,
				TravelStatus_code: "O"
			});

			// Bind the view to the created context
			view.setBindingContext(wizardContext);
			// Set the UI model property to make the forms and table editable
			view.getModel("ui").setProperty("/isEditable", true);
		} catch (error) {
			MessageBox.error("Failed to create travel request: " + (error as Error).message);
		}
	}

	/**
	 * Handler called when the submit button is pressed.
	 */
	public async onSubmitTravelRequest(): Promise<void> {
		// Navigate to the Object Page
		const routing = this.getExtensionAPI().getRouting();
		routing.navigate(this.getView().getBindingContext() as Context);
	}
}

You now have a working wizard structure with four steps! Before rendering the view, the controller's onBeforeRendering() method creates a new draft travel request and binds it to the view, so all our building blocks automatically work with this draft data. The onSubmitTravelRequest() method will be used later to finalize the wizard. For now, notice how the wizard steps are empty but navigable.

Preview wizard without step content

Step 2: Adding the First Form

Now let's add content to our first wizard step. This is where the portal becomes invaluable. You can either navigate to the Form Building Block in the same tab (the portal keeps your changes in memory as long as you don't refresh the browser), or better yet, open the portal in a second browser tab so you can reference the Form documentation while working on your wizard.

Open the Form page in the portal. You'll see it demonstrates the UI.FieldGroup#ApprovalData annotation. But we want to use a different field group for our first step. To see what's available, click "Show Code" next to the annotations example and look at the annotations.cds file in the code editor. You'll find several field groups, including TravelData, which is perfect for our first step.

Back in your wizard code, update the first WizardStep to include the form:

<WizardStep
	id="travelDataStep"
	title="Travel Information"
	validated="true"
>
	<MessageStrip
		text="Please provide the basic information about your travel request."
		type="Information"
		class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom"
	/>
	<macros:Form
		id="travelDataForm"
		metaPath="@UI.FieldGroup#TravelData"
	/>
</WizardStep>

Run the sample and navigate to the first step. You'll see the form with the travel data fields. 

Preview of first wizard step

Notice that the TravelID field appears as the first field. However, since travel IDs are calculated in the backend, it doesn't make sense to show this field here.

Let's remove it from the field group. Go back to the annotations.cds code editor and locate the TravelData field group. Remove the TravelID field:

FieldGroup #TravelData : {
	{ Value : BeginDate },
	{ Value : EndDate },
	{ Value : AgencyID },
	{ Value : CustomerID }
}

Click the "Run" button to refresh the preview with your changes - the TravelID field disappears! This demonstrates the power of annotation-driven UIs: simple metadata changes directly affect the user interface without touching the view code.

Preview without travel ID

Step 3: Adding the Budget & Approval Form

Now let's add the second form. Update the second WizardStep:

<WizardStep
	id="approvalDataStep"
	title="Budget and Approval"
	validated="true"
>
	<MessageStrip
		text="Provide budget information for approval."
		type="Information"
		class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom"
	/>
	<macros:Form
		id="approvalDataForm"
		metaPath="@UI.FieldGroup#ApprovalData"
	/>
</WizardStep>

This step uses the ApprovalData field group, which contains financial information like booking fee and total price. The same building block, configured differently through the metaPath property, delivers completely different content.

Preview second wizard step

Step 4: Adding the Bookings Table

The third step needs a table for managing flight bookings. Navigate to the Table Building Blocks in the portal. Study how the table building block works, paying special attention to the metaPath property.

For our wizard, we want to display bookings that are associated with the travel request. Since our view is bound to a Travel context, we need to set the metaPath to the bookings navigation. Update the third WizardStep:
 

<WizardStep
	id="bookingsStep"
	title="Bookings"
	validated="true"
>
	<VBox>
		<MessageStrip
			text="Add flight bookings for your travel. You can add multiple bookings."
			type="Information"
			class="sapUiSmallMarginBottom"
		/>

		<macros:Table
			id="bookingsTable"
			metaPath="/Travel/to_Booking/@UI.LineItem"
			personalization="Sort,Column"
			header="Flight Bookings"
			creationMode="NewPage"
		/>
	</VBox>
</WizardStep>

Run the sample and navigate to the Bookings step. Click the "Create" button in the table toolbar. You can now create bookings! The table building block automatically provides creation, editing, and deletion capabilities based on the entity's capabilities defined in the service metadata. This is enterprise-grade functionality delivered through a single building block with minimal configuration.

Preview third wizard step

Step 5: Submitting the Travel Request

The final step allows users to review and submit their travel request. Update the fourth WizardStep:

<WizardStep
	id="reviewStep"
	title="Submit Travel Request"
	validated="true"
>
	<VBox class="sapUiContentPadding">
		<Text
			text="You have successfully completed all steps. Your travel request is ready to be submitted."
			class="sapUiMediumMarginBottom"
		/>

		<HBox justifyContent="End" class="sapUiMediumMarginTop">
			<Button
				text="Submit"
				type="Emphasized"
				press="onSubmitTravelRequest"
				icon="sap-icon://paper-plane"
			/>
		</HBox>
	</VBox>
</WizardStep>

 Notice that we're not saving the draft directly using the EditFlow controller extension. Instead, when users click "Submit", the onSubmitTravelRequest method in our controller uses the routing API to navigate to the travel request's Object Page:

public async onSubmitTravelRequest(): Promise<void> {
	// Navigate to the Object Page
	const routing = this.getExtensionAPI().getRouting();
	routing.navigate(this.getView().getBindingContext() as Context);
}

With this approach, users can review their complete travel request in the standard Object Page layout, make any final changes, and then save it using the familiar Object Page header actions. This demonstrates an important principle: you can mix custom pages with standard floorplans in the same application, using each where it fits best.

The Power of Building Blocks in Custom Pages

What we've built demonstrates the core value proposition of SAP Fiori elements building blocks in custom pages:

  • Rapid Development - We created a sophisticated multi-step wizard with forms, tables, and draft handling in minutes, not days
  • Enterprise Features - Each building block brings personalization, validation, error handling, and accessibility automatically
  • Annotation-Driven - Business logic changes (like removing the TravelID field) require only metadata updates, not code changes
  • Consistency - The forms and table in our wizard look and behave exactly like those in standard floorplans, ensuring UI consistency
  • Flexibility - We combined building blocks with standard UI5 controls (Wizard, MessageStrip, Button) to create a layout not available in standard floorplans

Key Takeaways

When building custom pages with SAP Fiori elements:

  • Choose Wisely - Use standard floorplans whenever possible. Resort to custom pages only when your layout requirements genuinely don't fit standard patterns
  • Maximize Building Block Usage - The more you use SAP Fiori elements building blocks in your custom pages, the more enterprise features you get for free
  • Leverage the Portal - Use the SAP Fiori development portal to understand building block capabilities, experiment with configurations, and see immediate results
  • Mix and Match - Combine custom pages with standard floorplans in the same application, using each where appropriate
  • Stay Annotation-Driven - Even in custom pages, let annotations drive as much behavior as possible to minimize code and maximize maintainability

What's Next

In our final post, "Bringing the SAP Fiori development portal and its use to the next level (6 of 6)," we'll explore options to advance portal features and how to best include all project team members for maximizing productivity.

 

To get the full overview about the SAP Fiori development portal, check out the following blog posts of the mini-series:
  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6)
  • Get familiar with SAP Fiori development portal and the power of the building blocks (2 of 6)
  • Explore the potential of SAP Fiori development portal using complex building blocks (3 of 6)
  • Use SAP Fiori development portal to understand extension options for standard floorplans (4 of 6)
  • Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
  • Bringing the SAP Fiori development portal and its use to the next level (6 of 6)
