entry.title: A Practical Real-Time CTI Widget for SAP Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
Over the last weeks, I've been working on a CTI widget for SAP Sales Cloud V2 and wanted to share the practical setup I used to get it running in a production-ready way. The goal was simple: receive real-time call events from a telephony system and push them into Sales Cloud without relying on any custom back-end inside the CRM.

A small CAP backend, a WebSocket channel, and a UI5 widget were enough to make this work end-to-end.

Overall Architecture

The widget runs in an iframe inside SAP Sales Cloud. A CAP service on BTP receives call events from the telephony provider and forwards them to the widget via WebSocket. The widget then sends a formatted XML payload back to Sales Cloud using postMessage.

 

CAP Service with WebSocket Support

The backend uses CAP v9 with Websocket enabled so the widget can react immediately to incoming call events.

@protocol: ['websocket', 'odata']
service WidgetService {
  action notifyEvent(
      date : String,
      caller : String,
      isAnonymous : String,
      callee : String,
      event : String,
      direction : String,
      LID : String
  ) returns String;

  event eventNotification : CTIEvent;
}

Event Handler is handling the incoming event and emits it to connected WebSocket clients. 

this.on("notifyEvent", async (req) => {
  const eventData = req.data;
  await this.emit('eventNotification', eventData);
  return 'OK';
});

WebSocket channel is enabled using the @cap-js-community/websocket plugin. Also we configured the xs-app.json file.

{
"websockets": {
    "enabled": true
  }
}

Mapping the CTI Event for Sales Cloud

Sales Cloud expects a specific XML payload.
The widget maps incoming CTI data into that format.

function mapToSapPayload(cti) {
  const ev = (cti.event ?? "").toUpperCase();
  const dir = (cti.direction ?? "").toUpperCase();

  let eventType = dir === "OUTBOUND" ? "OUTBOUND" : "INBOUND";
  let action = "NOTIFY";

  switch (ev) {
    case "CONNECTED":
    case "ANSWERED":
      action = "ACCEPT";
      break;
    case "ENDED":
      action = "END";
      eventType = "UPDATEACTIVITY";
      break;
  }

  return {
    Type: "CALL",
    EventType: eventType,
    Action: action,
    ANI: cti.caller || "",
    ExternalReferenceID: cti.LID
  };
}

Sending the Event to Sales Cloud (postMessage)

The widget sends the XML using a postMessage call. After that, SAP Sales Cloud receives it and Desktop Agent creating a new live Interaction. See more in @lloyd_goveia 's post called 'How Can You Simplify SAP Service Cloud CTI Integration Testing? Try This Dynamic POC Widget!'.

const xml = jsonToXml(sapPayload);
window.parent.postMessage(xml, "*");

Here is an example payload. See more in SAP Help Portal.

<payload>
  <Type>CALL</Type>
  <EventType>INBOUND</EventType>
  <Action>NOTIFY</Action>
  <ANI>+123456789</ANI>
  <ExternalReferenceID>CALL123</ExternalReferenceID>
</payload>

SAP Sales Cloud reads sent mesagge only if CTI is enabled for the tenant, follow the SAP Help Portal doc for more detail. 

Security Notes

The SAP Sales Cloud domain was added to the App Router allowlist (whitelist) to ensure that SAP Cloud is able to load the widget in an iframe. we need to configure the whitelistService propery in xs-app.json.

{
  "whitelistService": {
    "endpoint": "/whitelist/service"
  },
  "responseHeaders": [
    {
      "name": "Content-Security-Policy",
      "value": "frame-ancestors https://*.crm.cloud.sap"
    }
  ],
  "routes": [
    {
      "source": "^/whitelist/service$",
      "localDir": ".",
      "authenticationType": "none",
      "cacheControl": "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate"
    }
}

For more information, please visit @sap/approuter in npmjs.com.

Configure SAP Sales Cloud CTI Configuration

There are a few CTI settings that need to be enable first to make the widget show up inside SAP Sales Cloud V2. 

  • Enable CTI Integration --> See SAP Help Portal
  • Register the Widget --> See SAP Help Portal 

Source Code 

The base code is available on Github as a public repo.

Repository Name: gizemsoylutr/sales-cloud-cti-widget

entry.title: Understanding Regex in JavaScript - A Beginner-Friendly Guide
entry.content:
Quick Introduction:

When working with JavaScript, we will often find ourselves needing to search, validate or modify text. That’s where Regex comes in.

In this blog, we will break down what regex is, why it’s useful, and how to start using it with simple examples.

 

What is Regex?

Regex is a powerful & smart search tool that lets you find patterns in text almost like giving your code a mini detective to look for clues inside a string.

Regex (short for Regular Expression) is a special pattern used to search, match and replace text.

In other words, regex is a pattern-matching language used in many programming languages, including JavaScript to:

  • Search for text
  • Match specific patterns
  • Replace parts of a string

For example, we might need to check if a sentence contains a word, extract all numbers from a paragraph or validate an email address. Regex makes these tasks fast, efficient and reliable.

 

Why do use Regex in JavaScript?

Because normal search is limited. With regex, we can do so much. Regex lets you write dynamic, flexible patterns to handle more advanced text operations. Here’s what you can do with it:

  1. Validate patterns

    Modify text based on matching patterns.
    Example: Remove extra spaces or replace characters.

  2. Extraction Text

    Check if a string follows a specific format.
    Example: Is this a valid email address?

  3. Replace text

    Pull out numbers, words or custom text patterns.
    Example: Find all digits in a message.

 

Simple and Practical Examples

Let’s look at how we can use regex in JavaScript with just a few lines of code.

  • Check if a word exists
const sText = "I love JavaScript";

const bResult = /JavaScript/.test(text);

console.log(bResult); // true
  • Find all numbers in a string
const sText = "My score is 95 out of 100.";

const sNumbers = sText.match(/\d+/g);

console.log(sNumbers); // ["95", "100"]
  • Replace spaces with dashes
const sResult = "hello world js".replace(/\s/g, "-");

console.log(sResult); // "hello-world-js"

 

How regex patterns are structured & how it works

Regex patterns in JavaScript are written between forward slashes:

/pattern/

Here are some common symbols:

Symbol

Meaning

\d

digit (0–9)

\s

whitespace (space, tab, etc.)

\w

word character (letters, numbers, _)

+

one or more

*

zero or more

Based on our requirement, we can combine these symbols to create almost any pattern we need.

In simple words, Regex is a smart text-searching tool in JavaScript. It helps us work with text faster, cleaner, and more efficiently, especially when dealing with patterns. Whether you're searching, matching or validating text, regex makes the process powerful, flexible and easy.

Thank you for taking the time to read this blog! I hope this helps you. If you found this helpful, please feel free to share your thoughts, feedback or questions in the comments. Let's keep learning and growing together!

Stay tuned for more in-depth knowledge on regex tool in future blogs. Happy coding!

Dear experts, I’m new to blogging, please feel free to correct me if any information is inaccurate.

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – In-depth analysis of SAP Fiori content changes during system upgrade
entry.content:
TL;DR SAP Fiori content can change during upgrades. Not only the app lifecycle influences the app availability and usage, attributes of SAP Fiori apps (e.g. tile title, application resource, …) can change as well and this will have an impact on your end users UX, if you don’t pay attention and address it via change procedures.

If you upgrade your SAP S/4HANA system version, there will be changes in the availability of SAP Fiori apps. Some will be deprecated, available with successor, obsolete/unavailable, or are not affected by any change. This will be highlighted by the SAP Fiori Upgrade Impact Analysis.   

The necessary prerequisites related to the SAP Fiori Upgrade Impact Analysis can be found either in the SAP Blog SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Upgrade Impact Analysis or on the SAP Help page SAP Fiori Upgrade Impact Analysis.
Additionally, the following SAP Blog offers you insights in the app lifecycle of SAP Fiori apps: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – Upgrade Faster – Managing app lifecycle impacts on users.

After reading through these documentations, you should be aware of the SAP Fiori upgrade process and what the app lifecycle statuses (deprecated, obsolete, available with successor, …) are referring to.

Let’s get into the details of what changes can occur in SAP Fiori content during a system upgrade.

Type of changes to SAP Fiori content

  1. Changes in the features/functionalities of SAP Fiori apps
    Please check the What's New Viewer - ABAP Platform to get updates on the functional changes happening in the SAP Fiori apps.
  2. Changes to feature/functionalities in the SAP Fiori launchpad
    Please check the What's New Viewer - ABAP Platform to get updates on the new features delivered with each SAP Fiori FES version.
  3. Changes to SAP Fiori Launchpad App Descriptor Items (LADI)
    This is the focus topic of this SAP Blog, as it is scope of the “Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis”.

SAP Fiori App changes on LADI

There is a multitude of changes that can happen during an SAP Fiori Upgrade.

In this blog I decided to use an upgrade scenario from SAP S/4HANA 2022 FPS01 to SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 as a case example. During my evaluation I used the SAP standard roles to illustrate the changes that can happen.
We are going to use four types of change priorities to describe the change impact of relevant LADI attributes that impacts end users.


To get a list of all LADI relevant attributes we are using the transaction /UI2/FLPCA for exporting… With this export we are able to get a quick overview of the SAP Fiori content in customer or SAP standard roles.

In SAP S/4HANA 2023 the report has a total of 63 columns that can be exported.
Out of these 63 a total of 22 can contain end user relevant changes.
If you see that a column appears multiple times, that column can contain different type of issues.

For instance,  the column Title/Subtitle/Information can contain issues related to:

  • Change of information displayed on tile
    This is rated as Medium
  • {Reference Lost} or {Reference Lost to Backend Catalog}
    This is rated as High

Below, you see an overview of the different end user relevant columns prioritized by possible impact during system upgrade.

*rating of these attributes can vary based on your end users change resilience/innovation acceptance threshold

Now, let’s dive into some specific examples to make this topic more tangible.

One more comment before showing some examples…
These apps are chosen without any additional intention behind displaying them.
The examples are chosen at random

1. Title/Subtitle/Information changed

As an example, we are going to take the roles SAP_BR_CONTRACT_MANAGER_CCM and SAP_BR_CONTR_MGR_ROYALTIES.
The structure of this field is as follows: Tile Title – Tile Subtitle / Tile Information

In the picture below you can see that we have a small change, information from the Tile Title has been written into the Tile Subtitle.

How is this change reflected in the SAP Fiori launchpad?

2. Application resource changed

The following example from role SAP_BR_BUDGET_RESPONSIBLE shows that in the business catalog SAP_PSM_BC_BDGTRESP_MD the application resource for the tile “Display Grant” changed.

As depicted in the screenshot below, taken from SE93, the programs behind these transactions are different. This can have a functional impact.
Your functional colleagues need to review, if the application is still suited to perform all the necessary process steps designated to that application.

3. Semantic Object and Action changed

The combination of semantic object and action is used for the intent-based navigation.

As this is relevant for the navigation network/flow of applications connected with each other, a potential change can have an impact on the process flow of end users working with these applications.

If such a change is detected, the applications in its process flow need to be verified again.

With these examples shown, I don’t want to discourage you in performing upgrades.
Rather I want to highlight the importance of proper testing during upgrades.
The SAP Fiori content can and will change during a system upgrade.
Preparing for this change via change management is crucial to ease your end users into the new SAP S/4HANA version.

Changes in Z-roles created with SAP standard content

You followed the SAP best-practices and copied the SAP standard business catalogs to your own Z-version of these content entities?
Independent of whether you are using SAP created business catalogs or business catalogs created by you, they are all referencing to the content from the technical catalogs.
If a LADI object changes in the original persistence (technical catalog), the LADI object will be changed in the reference (business catalog), as well.
Therefore, even if you use Z-catalogs and reference content from SAP technical catalogs, your content will be affected from the changes coming with the SAP Fiori upgrade as well.

This is a double-edged sword:

  1. You are getting changes from SAP standard content by referencing from SAP technical catalogs and therefore stay close to SAP Standard.
  2. Changes to content in SAP technical catalogs are reflected in your referenced content added to your business catalogs and hence will be in your system after the upgrade.

Since this is the best practice for multiple reasons, your content is going to change with an upgrade of the system version.

Now to the big question: can we support you in the process of SAP Fiori upgrade by highlighting these changes directly in your customer specific roles?

Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis

The Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis is a SAP delivered service providing you with the results via a service report to give you clarity on SAP Fiori changes during an upgrade.
We are combining the learnings from analysing the content in one source of truth and highlight the changes with recommendations fitting to each of these different changes.

What is required to perform the Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis?

We need two different exports to perform the in-depth analysis.

  1. SAP Fiori content of customer source system, this is an export of all customer relevant role data before the upgrade.
  2. SAP Fiori content of customer target system, this is an export of all customer relevant role data after the upgrade.

 

It is recommended to export the role data from the development system before performing an upgrade to a higher SAP S/4HANA version.
Ideally, no further changes to the role content are taken after the export has been performed.

The analysis of the content changes is conducted on entry level.
An entry is equal to an application, in a role in a catalog.

E.g. ME23N is in business catalog Z_BC_MM_PUR_DIS assigned to role Z_BR_MM_PUR_DIS.
Each entry in your custom roles can be sorted into the following categories:

1. Unchanged

This means that all end user relevant attributes of the SAP Fiori content remain unchanged and the application lifecycle status is “available” or “unknown”.

2. Changed

This means that at least one end user relevant attribute of the SAP Fiori content changes and/or the application lifecycle status is “obsolete”, “deprecated”, “available with successor”.

Changes on LADI level are highlighted, e.g. change on Title/Subtitle/Information.

3. Added

This means that the entry is part of the SAP Fiori content after the upgrade, e.g. got added by your administrators before taking the export or can’t be matched correctly due to reference lost issues.

4. Removed

This means that the entry is part of the SAP Fiori content before the upgrade, but not after.
E.g. got deleted by your administrators before taking the export or can’t be matched correctly due to reference lost issues

 How can you order this service?

If you already are a Premium Engagement customer, contact your SAP Technical Quality Manager (TQM) to discuss how Premium Engagement Service can help you with a custom-tailored and efficient service portfolio to make your project a success!
With the Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis, we are happy to support you with tailored insights and guidance for your system upgrade!
Discover further insights into SAP Premium Engagement and explore how an international team of specialists can assist you in maximizing the value of your SAP solutions.

If you are not a Premium Engagement customer and still want to take advantage of the Advanced Upgrade Impact Analysis, please align with your SAP Service Partner or SAP Account Responsible.

entry.title: Harmonizing UI5 URLs: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN
entry.content:
What Do We Do?

To further enhance consistency and ease of access, we are now making the convenient URLs the new default for all Demo Kit  resources. The following table shows the previous URLs and their short an convenient URLs:

Previous URLs

Short and Convenient URLs

openui5nightly.hana.ondemand.com

sdk.openui5.org/nightly

openui5.hana.ondemand.com

sdk.openui5.org

sapui5.hana.ondemand.com

ui5.sap.com

This follows our initial announcement “Short and Powerful: Convenient URLs for SAPUI5/OpenUI5 CDN”.

Why We’re Doing This

One URL for OpenUI5 and one for SAPUI5 improves search engine indexing and discoverability which will lead to better search results. It will simplify the access to our documentation and tools for developers and establishes consistent and future-proof domains which are independent from the platform they are served from.

What Will Happen?

To make the transition as easy as possible, we will gradually redirect users to the new URLs. Here’s what you can expect:

  • Demo Kit Resources (HTML pages) will be automatically redirected to the new URLs starting on:
    • OpenUI5: December 8th
    • SAPUI5: January 7th
  • Runtime Resources (everything else) will be redirected to the new URLs starting on:
    • OpenUI5: January 7th
    • SAPUI5: ~UI5con Germany 2026

These steps are designed to give everyone plenty of time to adjust to the new URLs and ensure a seamless experience.

What You Should Do Now

Make use of the short and convenient URLs now by...

  • ...updating your bookmarks to the Demo Kit to use the new domains
  • ...adopting your applications to bootstrap OpenUI5 or SAPUI5 from the new domains
  • ...sharing this update with your teams and communities to help us spreading this information (Hint: still the old netweaver.ondemand.com URLs are in use!!)

Although we redirect the existing URLs they are going to continue to work. Once the old URLs will be sunset, we’ll inform you early enough upfront.

Note: To bootstrap SAPUI5 in non-cloud scenarios please use the Standard Variant for Bootstrapping. See details on the difference in Docu: Bootstrapping from Content Delivery Network and in note 2943781.

Another note on Tracking Prevention when using these URLs: Please mind the respective information in "Browser and Platform Support" for SAPUI5 / OpenUI5 and note 3216225 on how to handle it.

entry.title: Consuming your own (or external) Web Components in UI5 Applications
entry.content:
Consuming your own (or external) Web Components in UI5 Applications

This post summarizes my learnings on how to consume arbitrary web components natively in UI5 applications. This is a powerful alternative to UI5 custom controls, since web components are framework-agnostic and can be reused in other contexts as well.

A lot of people perceive UI5 as a control library only, or at least a frontend framework that is very closely tied to its control library, but it's actually much more than that. It's a very powerful and flexible framework that can be extended and used in many different ways.

During the Developer Keynote at SAP TechEd on Tour Bangalore 2025 (no online recording unfortunately), I demoed the flexibility and openness of UI5 by showing two approaches for extending UI5 application with custom elements:

The first approach has been around for quite a while and is well known: developing UI5 custom controls. With this approach, you essentially create new UI5 controls by extending existing UI5 controls. This approach has the advantage of being fully integrated into the UI5 framework, but it also means it is tightly coupled to UI5. You cannot reuse UI5 custom controls for applications that are not based on UI5. However, since third-party packages (e.g. from npm) can be consumend inside UI5 applications as well (see ui5-tooling-modules), this approach is by no means limited. Check out this repository for detailed instructions on how to build a UI5 custom control that renders a 3D model of a supermarket to guide customers to a product's location: ui5-advanced-exercises-codejam

The second approach is very new to UI5: building your own web components and consuming them natively in UI5 applications. This approach is framework-agnostic, as the technologies that make up web components are open web standards. This means you can (re)use the same web components in any web application, regardless of the framework. Think of whole design systems that could be built using this approach, and then be reused in UI5/React/Angular/Vue applications alike! This blog post focuses on this second approach.

To demonstrate this capability, we first need a web component. For the sake of simplicity, I created a very basic web component that displays a button, and when clicked, shows an alert. The code for the web component looks like this:

class CustomAlertButton extends HTMLElement {

    static get observedAttributes() {
        return [
            "text",
            "message"
        ]
    }

    attributeChangedCallback(name, oldValue, newValue) {
        this.render()
    }

    constructor() {
        super()

        /**
         * Sets the button's text.
         * @default "Show Alert"
         * @public
         */
        this.text = "Show Alert"

        /**
         * Sets the alert message.
         * @default ""
         * @public
         */
        this.message = ""

        this.attachShadow({ mode: "open" })
        this.render()
    }

    render() {
        const text = this.getAttribute("text") || this.text
        const message = this.getAttribute("message") || this.message
        let button
        if (!this.shadowRoot.querySelector("button")) {
            button = document.createElement("button")
            this.shadowRoot.appendChild(button)
        } else {
            button = this.shadowRoot.querySelector("button")
            button.textContent = text
            if (message) {
                button.addEventListener("click", async () => {
                    alert(message)
                })
            }
        }
    }
}

customElements.define("custom-alert-button", CustomAlertButton)

There are two things important to note regarding the implementation above:

  1. For some reason I don't fully understand yet, the render method of the web component will get executed three times when the component is first rendered in a UI5 application. Therefore, the method includes some conditional logic to avoid adding multiple buttons or event handlers to the shadow DOM.
  2. The static getter observedAttributes as well as the JSDoc comments in the constructor method are mandatory in order for UI5 to be able to recognize the web component correctly and integrate it into its data binding and property system. Furthermore, we have to generate a custom-elements.js manifest file that describes the web component's API. This can be done using the @custom-elements-manifest/analyzer package. After installing it as a dev dependency, you can run the following command to generate the manifest file:
custom-elements-manifest analyze

This will create a custom-elements.json file in the root of your project. The file tree of your custom web component package should now look like this:

custom-webc-package/
|-- custom-elements.js
|-- CustomAlertButton.js
|-- package.json

With the custom web component package ready, we can now consume it in a UI5 application. To do so, we first need to install it as a dependency. In the package.json of the UI5 application, add it as a dependency and run npm install afterwards:

...
{
  "dependencies": {
    "custom-webc-package": "file:<path-to-your-custom-webc-package>"
  }
}
...

At this point you might be thinking "wait, I can just declare any package as a dependency and use it in UI5?!" - and the answer is yes, with the help of the ui5-tooling-modules package, which allows you to consume arbitrary npm packages in UI5 applications. So make sure you have it set up in your UI5 application.

Now that the custom web component package is installed, its consumption is very straightforward. Simply declare a namespace in an XML view that points to the package, and use the web component like any other UI5 control:

<mvc:View
    ...
    xmlns:webc="custom-webc-package">
    ...
    <webc:custom-alert-button
        text="Click Me!"
        message="Hello from my custom web component!" />
    ...

Now, to top off this exmaple, one more thing worth mentioning: In our web component implementation, we can even import and use other web components, for example UI5 web components. The UI5 web components have the same look and feel as the standard UI5 controls, but they are built on top of web component technologies, so they too are framework-agnostic (just like our own custom web component). In our example, we can replace the standard HTML button with the ui5-button web component from the UI5 web components library:

import "@ui5/webcomponents/dist/Button.js"

class CustomAlertButton extends HTMLElement {

    ...

    render() {
        const text = this.getAttribute("text") || this.text
        const message = this.getAttribute("message") || this.message
        let button
        if (!this.shadowRoot.querySelector("ui5-button")) {
            button = document.createElement("ui5-button")
            this.shadowRoot.appendChild(button)
        } else {
            button = this.shadowRoot.querySelector("ui5-button")
            button.textContent = text
            if (message) {
                button.addEventListener("click", async () => {
                    alert(message)
                })
            }
        }
    }
}

customElements.define("custom-alert-button", CustomAlertButton)

We have now come full-circle: We created a custom web component, which by design is framework-agnostic, and used a UI5 web component inside of it. We consumed the custom web component in a UI5 application, demonstrating the flexibility and openness of the UI5 framework, and we could take this same web component to any other application as well, be it UI5 or not.

Try it out yourself and let me know how it goes!

entry.title: Bridging Data Quality Gaps in SAP SuccessFactors TIH with CSVValidationApp and Vibe Coding
entry.content:
Introduction

Data quality challenges in SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub (TIH) often go unnoticed until they impact user experience. When thousands of attributes are imported without proper validation, issues like HTML tags, broken formatting, and unescaped characters can disrupt Growth Portfolios and compromise analytics/employee experience. This blog introduces CSVValidationApp, a solution designed to bridge this gap using functional expertise and modern development practices like Vibe Coding—and opens the door for community collaboration on similar innovations.

Why This Matters

 SAP Talent Intelligence Hub is a strategic enabler for skills-based workforce planning. It helps organizations create dynamic career paths, leverage AI-driven skill recommendations, and empower employees through Growth Portfolios. These capabilities unlock smarter talent decisions and a more agile workforce.

To fully realize these benefits, data integrity during imports is critical. According to SAP Help Portal, importing entities like attributes, tags, and behaviors into TIH requires strict adherence to structure and format. Common issues include:

  • Incorrect headers or missing mandatory fields in CSV files
  • Improper encoding (non-UTF-8) causing character display errors
  • Unescaped quotes or HTML tags in descriptions, which can truncate or break content
  • Large file sizes impacting performance (recommended limit: 25,000 records per file)
  • Incorrect date formats for proficiencyAssignedDate when updating Growth Portfolio attributes

These challenges can lead to incomplete or inaccurate data in the Attributes Library and Growth Portfolio, affecting AI-driven recommendations and user experience. Adding a validation step before import ensures clean, consistent data—reducing manual troubleshooting and enabling HR teams to focus on strategic initiatives.

My Perspective and Approach

Having worked extensively across implementations, integrations, and functional solution design in SuccessFactors, I’ve seen how small data issues can create big challenges downstream. This experience shaped my approach: build a tool that doesn’t just validate data but actively improves it before it enters TIH.

I chose Vibe Coding as the development approach because it accelerates delivery through real-time collaboration, instant previews, and iterative design—all within SAP Business Application Studio. This allowed me to focus on business logic and user experience rather than boilerplate coding, ensuring the solution was delivered quickly without compromising quality.

How CSVValidationApp Fits into the TIH Workflow

CSVValidationApp acts as a data quality gatekeeper in the integration process. In the following example workflow after data is exported from Integration Center, the file passes through CSVValidationApp for cleansing and validation. Once clean, the data is transformed and mapped to TIH-compatible attributes before being imported back into the system.

This workflow ensures that what enters TIH is not just valid but optimized for rendering and usability. The result? A clean, enriched skills library that supports AI-driven recommendations and future enhancements.

What Makes CSVValidationApp Powerful

CSVValidationApp performs comprehensive checks tailored for SuccessFactors Integration Center requirements. It detects encoding issues, validates structure, identifies problematic characters, and removes HTML tags and entities. Beyond validation, it offers auto-correction, generating clean content with proper quoting and escaping. A preview feature and detailed statistics give administrators confidence before import.

By automating these steps, CSVValidationApp transforms a tedious, error-prone process into a seamless experience—empowering HR teams to focus on strategic tasks rather than data cleanup.

Looking Ahead: Unlocking the Full Potential of TIH

SAP Talent Intelligence Hub is continuously evolving to help organizations stay ahead in a skills-based economy. Upcoming innovations include AI-driven skill inference, integration with external taxonomies, expanded APIs, and advanced analytics for workforce agility. These capabilities will empower HR teams to make smarter decisions and deliver personalized employee experiences.

Clean, validated data is the foundation for these advancements. By ensuring data integrity from the start, organizations can confidently leverage AI recommendations, predictive insights, and future integrations without disruption.

CSVValidationApp supports this vision by acting as a proactive data quality gatekeeper. Future enhancements will include AI-powered attribute correction suggestions, direct SAP API integration for one-click imports, and support for additional modules like Learning and Recruiting—making the process even more seamless and intelligent.

Getting Started

CSVValidationApp is built as an SAP Fiori application using SAP Business Application Studio. To run it locally, simply clone the ***REMOVED BY MODERATION***, install dependencies, and start the app.

Here is an example screen shot from the application. The Attribute text file I validate below had many data rows with competency description such as: 
"1000009","de_DE","BUSINESS & TRANSFORMATION..","<p>Sie planen Ihre Vorhaben, definieren herausfordernde Ziele und entscheiden mutig.</p><p>Herausforderungen im „VUCA“-Umfeld (Volatilität – Unsicherheit – Komplexität – Ambiguität) begegnen Sie aktiv und entwickeln eine klare Vision für Ihren Verantwortungsbereich.</p><p><a href= xyzurl target=_blank>Kriterien und Verhaltensanker</a> anzeigen.</p>","COMPETENCY"

 This description gets corrected to:

"1000009","de_DE","BUSINESS & TRANSFORMATION..","Sie planen Ihre Vorhaben, definieren herausfordernde Ziele und entscheiden mutig. Bei der Umsetzung agieren Sie lösungsorientiert, bewerten Ergebnisse und Prozesse und nehmen notwendige Anpassungen vor. Herausforderungen im „VUCA\"-Umfeld (Volatilität - Unsicherheit - Komplexität - Ambiguität) begegnen Sie aktiv und entwickeln eine klare Vision für Ihren Verantwortungsbereich. ","COMPETENCY"

Final Thoughts & Community Ask

Data quality may seem like a technical detail, but in reality, it’s a strategic enabler. By combining functional expertise with modern development practices, CSVValidationApp delivers a solution that not only solves today’s challenges but positions organizations for tomorrow’s opportunities.

I’d love to hear from the SAP Community:

  • Have you built similar tools using Vibe Coding or other rapid development approaches?
  • What other gaps do you see in data validation for SuccessFactors integrations, and how can we bridge them together?

Share your thoughts, examples, and ideas in the comments. Let’s collaborate to make data quality a strength, not a challenge.

entry.title: Bringing the SAP Fiori Development Portal and Its Use to the Next Level (6 of 6)
entry.content:
As we conclude our mini-series on the SAP Fiori development portal, where we provided you with everything needed to make the best possible choices for your project, it is now up to you to pick your set of building blocks and decide where to use what for your targeted SAP Fiori app. Let's consolidate key learnings that will help you maximize the portal's potential in your development workflow and look at the way forward.

Transform how you approach SAP Fiori app development

The SAP Fiori development portal represents more than just documentation - it's a comprehensive platform that transforms how you approach SAP Fiori app development. Whether you're a seasoned developer, a business analyst defining requirements, or a designer crafting user experiences, the portal provides real-time exploration options for building apps based on SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 to make informed decisions and build enterprise-grade applications efficiently.

Now it's time to consolidate what we've learned into actionable guidance that will help you maximize the portal's potential in your development workflow.

Tips and Tricks for Maximum Productivity

It is all about balancing standardization with customization. The portal structure and feature help you navigate the SAP Fiori elements for OData V4 options to maximize your success.

Portal Structure

The portal structure supports you in balancing standardization with customization.

  • Map business requirements to building blocks first - use the portal to identify which components can address your function needs out-of-the-box 
  • Leverage Global Patterns early in your project planning - these non-visual building blocks like draft handling and navigation patterns are often overlooked but critical for enterprise applications   
  • Evaluate standard floorplans against your use cases before building custom solutions - List Report and Object Page patterns handle the majority of business scenarios. Together with the extension points provided by SAP Fiori elements, they can often meet your requirements with minimal effort
  • Use Custom Pages for more creative app layouts - if the target picture of your application is too far from the standard floorplans, opt for custom page creation using building blocks and global patterns to get the benefits of the metadata-driven UIs, or leverage freestyle SAPUI5 to achieve your goal.

Portal Features

  • Use "Show Code" consistently - every page offers this feature to reveal the underlying annotations and implementation details
  • Experiment with live code editing - modify annotations in real-time to understand how changes affect the UI behavior. Switch off live mode for more complex code changes
  • Explore both display and edit modes - many building blocks behave differently in these modes, and the portal shows both scenarios
  • Follow "Documentation" links for detailed product documentation - the portal provides focused overviews while official docs offer comprehensive details

The Portal as Your Companion

The SAP Fiori development portal isn't just a reference - it's an active participant in your development process, already starting when designing the target picture. When mapping the business user needs to how this translates into application UI, you want to review the options in the SAP Fiori development portal since following standard patterns or use standard building blocks will reduce implementation and maintenance efforts drastically. By including the portal in your everyday development process, you'll find that it becomes an indispensable tool for delivering high-quality SAP Fiori applications efficiently.

As the portal continues to evolve, these fundamental approaches will serve you well. The combination of hands-on experimentation, systematic evaluation, and informed decision-making creates a development workflow that scales with your team's growth and adapts to changing business requirements.

While using it in your day-to-day work, help us understand what helps you the most, where things go in the right direction but lack the last mile, and inspire us for things we haven't even thought about yet.

Looking Forward – SAP Fiori elements is compatible with AI tooling

The SAP Fiori development portal represents our commitment to making SAP Fiori elements development more accessible, efficient, and collaborative. That also includes using its content and the learning when providing AI-based development support by SAP Fiori tools. As we continue to enhance the portal, remember that it's designed to grow with your expertise.

We can think in the following directions right now:

  • Enhance the level of detail for developers, e.g. . This also make makes the portal useful as a grounding document for AI tools and LLMs that assist developers with creating SAP Fiori elements apps
  • Include the designer persona much more - bridging to the SAP Design System for the basics and providing guidance for the use of available features of SAP Fiori elements based on the context
  • Connect the explorer world of the portal with the implementation world of SAP Fiori tools

Whether you're building your first SAP Fiori application or extending an existing enterprise solution, the portal provides the foundation for making informed decisions that balance rapid development with enterprise-grade quality. The building blocks, patterns, and guidance we've explored throughout this series are your tools for creating applications that users love and businesses depend on.

Thank you for joining us on this journey through the SAP Fiori development portal. We're excited to see the innovative applications you'll build using these tools and techniques. And maybe you are already one of the next customers presenting how the portal helped you in crafting your SAP Fiori app in the SAP Fiori development roundtable. Your feedback and experiences will continue to shape the portal's evolution, making it an even more powerful resource for the entire SAP Fiori development community.

Complete Blog Series Overview

To get the full overview of the SAP Fiori development portal, check out the following blog posts of the mini-series:

  • Introducing the SAP Fiori Development Portal: Your Gateway to Rapid SAP Fiori App Creation (1 of 6)
  • Get familiar with SAP Fiori development portal and the power of the building blocks (2 of 6)
  • Explore the potential of SAP Fiori development portal using complex building blocks (3 of 6)
  • Use SAP Fiori development portal to understand extension options for standard floorplans (4 of 6)
  • Prepare building custom pages by using SAP Fiori development portal (5 of 6)
  • Bringing the SAP Fiori development portal and its use to the next level (6 of 6)

entry.title: Steps by Step Guide to enable Joule in Fiori launchpad for S4HANA 2025 Cloud Private Edition
entry.content:
Hi All,

I am writing this blog which have the steps to enable the Joule Communication Scenario on your SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud instance and integrate Joule Web Client plugin in your SAP Fiori Launchpad, allowing your users to interact with Joule.

Below are the steps that are needed to achieve this.

  • Enable Joule Services, Cloud Identity Services (Connectivity) & SAP Build Work Zone , Standard Edition in a subaccount .
  • Establish Trust of Subaccount with the Identity Authentication tenant (IAS)
  • Configure Trusted Domain in SAP BTP
  • Enable Fiori launchpad login using your Identity Authentication tenant 
  • Configure Trusted Domains in Identity Authentication
  • Expose SAP Fiori Launchpad Content to SAP BTP
  • Set Up SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition as a Content Provider
  • Activating SAP Build Work Zone , SAP Joule & Cloud identity services in subaccount
  • Run the Joule Booster
  • Configure Destinations in BTP 
  • Configure Identity Provisioning Service
  • Configure and Activate Joule Plug-In in a Target Mapping

Note-1 : Your Cloud Identity Tenant and you BTP subaccount should be in same region 

Note-2 : In this blog we are using our corporate IDP to login to our BTP , IAS and Fiori.

Note-3 : Enablement of Joule is also available with Cloud Integration Automation service in which several steps are automated you can refer to below blog if you want to perform this automatically

Joule provisioning with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition using Cloud Integration Automation service 

 

Lets begin the manual setup

Enable Joule Services, Cloud Identity Services (Connectivity) & SAP Build Work Zone , Standard Edition in a subaccount .

Login to BTP subaccount in which you want to activate Joule.

click on enable cloud foundry - It will prompt you the name you want to keep you can keep default setting and click okay.

Go to entitlement and get services - Joule (foundation), SAP Built work Zone standard edition & SAP Cloud identity services (connectivity)

 

click on add 3 service plans --> Click save

Establish Trust of Subaccount with the Identity Authentication tenant (IAS)

Go to trust configuration in your BTP subaccount

click on establish trust

 

click next and choose the domain & click next and finish the wizard

Configure Trusted Domain in SAP BTP

  1. Go to your subaccount and choose Security  Settings.

  2. Choose + (Add).

  3. Enter the host name for the trusted domain.

  4. For example: https://store.example.com

  5. All the trusted domains together, including their space separators, can't exceed 2048 characters.

  6. Save your entries.

 

add your Fiori URL domain here.

Enable Fiori launchpad login using your Identity Authentication tenant 

This is critical step in the configuration because all BTP services works with IAS authentication and our on premise solution i.e. S4HANA should also work with IAS authentication.

Below are steps to achieve this.

  1. Get the SAML Metadata of Your Identity Authentication Tenant
  2. Create an App for Your SAP S/4HANA Solution
  3. Enable the ABAP Platform as an SAML Service Provider
  4. Trust Identity Authentication as an Identity Provider
  5. Set the Name ID Format for Your ABAP Platform Client
  6. Trust the ABAP Platform Client as a Service Provider
  7. Configuring the Subject Name Identifier Consumed by the ABAP Platform

I will be posting detailed step by step guide on how to enable this login using corporate IDP but to make this blog limited to Joule enablement I have provided direct link to help.sap guide

Configure Trusted Domains in Identity Authentication

  1. Sign in to the administration console for SAP Cloud Identity Services.

  2. Under Applications and Resources, choose the Tenant Settings tile.

    At the top of the page, you can view the administrative and license relevant information of the tenant.

  3. Under Customization, choose the Trusted Domains list item

  4. Press the + Add button.

  5. Type the URL of the trusted host in the field.

    You can type either the full name of the host or you can use the wild card * function.

    Caution

    Be careful when using the wild card * function. Make sure that you trust the domain when you use it.

    See the examples:

    mycompany.ondemand.com

    *.example.com

  6. Save your changes.

    If the operation is successful the system displays the message Trusted Domains updated.

Expose SAP Fiori Launchpad Content to SAP BTP

login to your S4HANA ABAP system

run tcode /n/UI2/CDM3_EXP_SCOPE

click on expose content

here we choose version 1 (note icf service  /sap/bc/ui2/cdm3 is activated)

 

Set Up SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition as a Content Provider

This step have few sub steps to be done

login to SAP cloud connector and add your subaccount that you created

 

you can download the authentication data file from the BTP subaccount --> connectivity --> Cloud connector  --> download authentication data

Then you can upload the same here 

select the subaccount which you added and click on cloud to on-premise

create two connections a) HTTPS and b) RFC as shown below

Activating SAP Build Work Zone , SAP Joule & Cloud identity services in subaccount

Go to your subaccount and click in instance and subscription

create below 3 services

you need to create instance for SAP Build work zone and create service key as well

 

Run Joule booster

Go to global account and select booster

Here carefully select your S4HANA private cloud system and your SAP Build work zone instance

it will create formation for joule to work

Configure destinations

In this steps you need to create 5 destinations 

  • Design-time Destination
  • Runtime Destination
  • Destination for retrieving nomination via SAP Cloud connector
  • Create a content provider
  • Single Sign-on Destination

Design-time Destination

In the SAP BTP cockpit, in your subaccount, navigate to Connectivity  Destinations.

Use the following properties to define the design-time destination:

Runtime Destination

Destination for retrieving nomination via SAP Cloud connector

Create content provider

  1. In the SAP BTP cockpit, log on to your subaccount as administrator.

  2. In your subaccount, go to Instances and Subscriptions and launch SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.

  3. In SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition, go to Channel Manager.

  4. Choose + New to add a new content provider.

 

 

Single-Sign on destination

 

Configure Identity Provisioning Service

Follow below link to perform this step

Configure Identity Provisioning Service 

 

Configure and Activate Joule Plug-In in a Target Mapping

Create Catalog in Fiori Launchpad

Go to the T-code: /n/UI2/FLP in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition system and Open the Fiori Launchpad Tab. Click on the Launchpad App Manager (Cross Client).

Create a new Techincal Catalog by clicking on the New Standard Catalog.

Click on ADD APP -> SAPUI5 Fiori App.

In the launchpad app manager (see e.g. Creating and Maintaining Launchpad App Descriptor Items), create a target mapping with the intent Shell-plugin and the following configuration:

In PFCG you can create role Z:Joule_S4HANA and add catalog to the role 

Then you can assign this role to the users you want joule icon to be enabled.

 

Now configuration is completed and you can login to fiori launchpad

entry.title: How to call a RAP action from your Controller Extension
entry.content:
Traditionally to improve performance of a Fiori application the roundtrips to the backend (OData Service) should be minimal. To achieve this, we can push some processing logic to the frontend, This Blog explores one of the option to do that.

RAP Action

One of RAP’s powerful capabilities is the concept of actions — custom operations tied to a business object that let you implement domain-specific logic in ABAP using the behaviour implementation class (e.g. “approve order,” “mass update statuses,” “trigger workflow,” etc.) rather than relying purely on standard CRUD behaviour.

When you want to expose such actions in the UI of your RAP based Fiori App, there are two ways you can do it,

  • Using OData Annotations
  • Using Controller extensions

This blog covers a basic scenario of adding a custom button on the list page.

Using OData Annotations

Using OData annotation is the easier way out and suggested by SAP. SAP don’t want ABAPers to think much about the front end, that’s where the Fiori elements come in which is standard UI5 library to deploy Fiori apps, using which any ABAPer can create a Fiori app without have any knowledge about UI5.

Fiori elements generate the Fiori app in runtime using

  • OData Annotations
  • OData Service
  • Standard Fiori Floorplans.

So, adding your annotations in the below manner to your CDS will add the custom action on your Fiori App.

For sake of simplicity, I am using a static action

Below is the metadata extension file containing the UI annotations

Result,

 

You can write the business logic for this action in the behaviour implementation class

Using Controller extensions

If your requirement is not fulfilled by using the OData Annotations, for instance you want to call multiple actions using a single button or push some processing to your frontend rather than the backend (Your OData Service). You can use application modeler to add a custom button in the front end.

You can add a custom button using Application Modeler and add a handler method in your Controller extension. Using this handler method, you can call the same custom action from the RAP OData V4 service.

In the below example I am adding a custom button on the list page in the table toolbar.

Make Sure that you have created a Controller Extension for the page you are adding the custom button to, you can do that using the application modeler as well

Once the custom action is added you can add the below logic to call the custom action of the OData Service, you can replace the endpoint as per your OData service

     

OnActionPress: async function() {
// Calling a custom action of RAP Bobj using Controller ext
console.log("OnActionPress");
// Getting service URL
var model = this.base.getExtensionAPI().getModel();
var url = model.sServiceUrl;

// Making a GET call to fetch CSRF Token
var getTokenResp = await fetch( url, { method: "GET", headers: 
{ "X-CSRF-Token": "Fetch", Accept: "application/json" },credentials: "same-origin"  });
var token = getTokenResp.headers.get("x-csrf-token");	

// Calling Custom action by making a POST call
var uploadEndpoint = url + "Y_C_UTILAPP_PG/SAP__self.Upload";
const uploadResp = await fetch(uploadEndpoint, {
                        method: "POST",
                        headers: {
                            "Content-Type": "application/json",
                            Accept: "application/json",
                            "X-CSRF-Token": token
                        },
                        credentials: "same-origin"
                    });
console.log("Calling a custom action of RAP Bobj using Controller ext"); }

Result

A similar custom button will be created

Pressing this button will trigger the handler method ‘OnActionPress’ which will make the POST call triggering the same ‘Upload’ static action of the RAP Business Object.

 

PS: Thank you for reading. I’ll be writing more blogs soon on RAP, OData, UI5, and flexible programming languages — hope to see you there!

entry.title: Building an Enterprise Application Using Fiori Elements and CAP - Part 1
entry.content:
This series focuses on building a full application using SAP CAP and Fiori Elements. The intention is to keep the setup simple enough for anyone new to the stack, while still following the standard project structure recommended for enterprise development. The goal is to understand how the backend and frontend fit together, and how CAP services can be used directly by Fiori Elements without writing custom front-end controllers. 

This first part prepares the CAP backend that will later serve as the data source for the Fiori Elements application.

1. Why CAP and Fiori Elements 

CAP provides a way to define data models, services, and business logic using CDS. It handles a large portion of the technical work such as OData exposure, validations, and persistence. This makes it easier to focus on the domain rather than the setup. 

Fiori Elements uses OData metadata and annotations to generate UI automatically. This reduces the amount of front-end coding needed and keeps the application aligned with SAP design guidelines. 

Together, CAP and Fiori Elements form a consistent stack for building enterprise applications with predictable structure and behavior. 

2. Choosing the CAP Runtime 

CAP applications can run on Node.js or Java. Both runtimes share the same modeling approach, but each has its own advantages. 

  • The Node.js runtime is commonly used when developing with SAP Fiori tools and when building full-stack applications. It has a simple setup and most CAP examples follow this runtime. 
  • The Java runtime fits teams that work mainly in Java or need integration with existing Java systems. 

For this series, the Node.js runtime is used because it provides a straightforward setup for linking with Fiori Elements. 

3. Prerequisites 

  • The following tools are required before starting: 
  • Node.js (LTS version recommended) 
  • SAP CDS development kit 
  • npm install -g @SAP/cds-dk 
  • Visual Studio Code 
  • SAP Fiori tools - Extension Pack (VS Code extension) 
  • SAP CDS Language Support (VS Code extension) 

These tools provide the environment needed for developing both the CAP backend and the Fiori Elements application. 

4. Creating the CAP Project 

Create a new folder for the project and initialize it: 

mkdir product-management 
cd product-management 
cds init

 This creates the standard CAP project structure as shown below:

  • The db folder is used for data models 
  • The srv folder contains the service definitions 
  • The app folder will later hold the Fiori Elements application 

5. Defining the Data Model 

Create a new file under folder ‘db’ as ‘schema.cds’ and define the Product entity: 

namespace my.products; 
entity Products {
    key ID          	: UUID;
    name            	: String(100);
    description     	: String(255);
    price           	: Decimal(9,2);
    stock           	: Integer;
    category        	: String(50);
    releaseDate     	: Date;
    isAvailable     	: Boolean;
}

This model creates the basic structure for product data. CAP will map this entity to a database table and generate OData metadata for it. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

6. Creating the Service 

Create the service file under folder ‘srv’ as ‘product-service.cds’ and expose the entity: 

using { my.products as my } from '../db/schema';
service ProductService {
    entity Products as projection on my.Products;
}

The projection makes the Products entity available as an OData V4 service. CAP automatically adds support for standard operations such as read, create, update, and delete. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

7. Adding Sample Data 

To load initial data at runtime, create a file named 'my.products-Products.csv' under 'db/data': 

ID,name,description,price,stock,category,releaseDate,isAvailable 
1,Laptop,A powerful laptop for all your computing needs,1200.00,50,Electronics,2024-01-15,true 
2,Headphones,High-quality noise-cancelling headphones,250.00,150,Electronics,2024-02-20,true 
3,Smartphone,The latest smartphone with a stunning camera,899.99,200,Electronics,2024-03-10,true 
4,Coffee Maker,A machine that brews a perfect cup of coffee,75.50,80,Home Appliances,2023-11-05,false 
5,Keyboard,A mechanical keyboard for a superior typing experience,125.00,120,Electronics,2024-04-01,true 
6,Blender,A high-speed blender for smoothies and more,99.99,60,Home Appliances,2023-12-15,true 
7,Desk Chair,Ergonomic desk chair for maximum comfort,180.00,40,Furniture,2024-02-28,true 
8,Monitor,A 27-inch 4K UHD monitor,350.00,70,Electronics,2024-03-25,true 
9,Vacuum Cleaner,A powerful vacuum cleaner for all floor types,150.00,90,Home Appliances,2023-10-30,true 
10,Tablet,A lightweight tablet perfect for on-the-go use,450.00,110,Electronics,2024-01-20,true

CAP reads this file automatically when the application starts. 

 

 

 

 

 

8. Running the Application 

Start the service locally: 

cds watch

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Once the server starts, open the brower with link http://localhost:4004 which will open the below endpoints


 

 

 

 

 

The ProductService link appears on the home page. Opening the Products entity displays the sample records in JSON format. This confirms that the service and data model are working as expected. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

9. Summary 

  • At this point, the backend is ready with: 
  • A clean data model 
  • An exposed OData V4 service 
  • Sample data for testing 
  • A structure prepared for Fiori Elements development 
  • This backend serves as the base for building the Fiori Elements application in the next part. 

Next Part 

The next part will focus on generating a Fiori Elements List Report application and connecting it to the ProductService created here. The List Report will display the product data and use annotations to control fields, behavior, and layout. 
Building an Enterprise Application Using Fiori Elements and CAP – Part 2

entry.title: Building an Enterprise Application Using Fiori Elements and CAP – Part 2
entry.content:
With the CAP backend ready from Part 1: Preparing the CAP Backend, the next step is to create a List Report and Object Page application using SAP Fiori Elements. This part explains how to generate the UI using the latest SAP Fiori tools generator and connect it to the ProductService created earlier. 

The flow in the current generator has changed compared to older tutorials, so this section follows the updated steps exactly as developers see them today in Visual Studio Code. 

1. Prerequisites 

Before generating the application, ensure the following: 

  • The CAP project from Part 1 is opened in Visual Studio Code 
  • The CAP server is running using: cds watch 
  • Visual Studio Code extensions installed: 
    • SAP Fiori tools – Extension Pack 
    • SAP CDS Language Support 

These are required for the generator and metadata integration. 

2. Opening the Application Generator 

Open the SAP Fiori tools Application Generator as follows: 

  • Open Visual Studio Code 
  • Open the Command Palette 
  • Run: Fiori: Open Application Generator 

This opens the updated generator UI. 

3. Selecting the Template 

Select the ‘List Report Page’ template, this template includes both the List Report and the Object Page, which is suitable for most business scenarios. 

Click Next to proceed

4. Data Source and Service Selection 

Choose the data source as ‘Use  a Local CAP Project’, which will allow us to choose any location CAP project to be used as data source for the project 

This option loads metadata directly from the CAP service running on cds watch. 

Once selected: 

  • Choose the product-management project (root project folder) 

  • The generator will detect available services
  • Select ProductService

  • Select the entity Products

 

Click Next. 

This step connects the UI to the CAP backend created in Part 1. 

 

5. Project Attributes 

The final screen asks for basic project details: 

  • Module name: productfe 
  • Title: Product Management 
  • Description: List Report and Object Page for Products 
  • Folder location: Accept default, which places it under the app folder 

 

 

Click Finish to generate the application. 

The generator creates the UI module inside: app/productfe

 

6. Understanding the Generated Structure 

The generated application includes: 

webapp/ 

Contains all UI resources, including routing, views, and layout configuration. 

webapp/manifest.json 

Defines: 

  • Data sources 
  • Routing 
  • List Report and Object Page configuration 
  • Annotation references 

annotations/ 

Optional location for local annotation XML files. 

ui5.yaml 

UI5 tooling configuration used for running and building the app. 

Root-level package.json 

Contains dependencies and scripts for serving the app locally. 

This structure is standard for Fiori Elements applications. 

 

7. Running the Application 

 

To preview the application: 

1. Ensure the CAP backend is still running with cds watch

2. Click on the Fiori Preview to see the list report 

 

The List Report should load and display the product data from the CSV file. 
Selecting a product navigates to the Object Page. 

No custom UI code is required at this stage. 
Everything is generated based on metadata coming from the CAP service. 

8. Adding Basic CDS Annotations 

 

Annotations help shape the UI. 
To define them centrally, create a file 'srv/annotations.cds'  Add the following:

 

using my.products as prod from '../db/schema.cds'; 

annotate prod.Products with @( 
    UI: { 
        HeaderInfo: { 
            TypeName:          'Product', 
            TypeNamePlural:    'Products',
            Title:             { Value: name }
        }, 

        SelectionFields: [
            name,
            category
        ],
        Identification: [
            { Value: name },
            { Value: description }
        ]
    }
);

 

These annotations define: 

  • Title and header information 
  • Search and filter fields 
  • Basic fields shown on the Object Page 

Save the file and refresh the preview to see the changes.

10. Summary 

With the List Report up and running and the first set of annotations applied, the application now has a working front end connected to the CAP service. The filters, titles, and basic layout are driven entirely by the annotations added in the CAP project, which helps set the foundation for more advanced UI behavior. 

At this stage, the Object Page is available as part of the template, but it has not been configured or enhanced yet. The template creates the routing and navigation automatically, but the actual Object Page layout and details are still very minimal. These parts will be handled in the next section of the series. 

The goal so far has been to make sure that the List Report is stable, the metadata is flowing correctly, and the annotations are being picked up as expected. Once these pieces are in place, adding and shaping the Object Page becomes much easier.  Building an Enterprise Application Using Fiori Elements and CAP – Part 3.

entry.title: Building an Enterprise Application Using Fiori Elements and CAP – Part 3
entry.content:
With the List Report in place from Part 2: Creating the List Report, the next natural step is to improve how each product looks when navigating to its details. The Object Page is completely annotation-driven, which means the way fields appear, how they are grouped, and how sections are displayed all depend on how the CDS annotations are written. 

This part starts by improving field labels using element-level annotations, then introduces the basic Object Page layout, and finally adds additional sections and groups to give the page a clean structure. One common navigation issue (UUID mismatch) is also explained along the way, since it usually appears right when developers first open the Object Page. 

1. Element-Level Annotations 

By default, the List Report and Object Page use the raw property names from the entity (name, category, etc.). This often results in labels appearing in lower case or with technical names. To make the fields more readable, element-level annotations allow each field to have a user-friendly label. 

Element-level annotations can be added in the same CDS file where you maintain the UI structure. In our setup, this file is:  srv/annotations.cds 

Below is a simple example of how to assign labels to each field: 

using my.products as prod from '../db/schema.cds';

annotate prod.Products with {
    name        @title: 'Product Name';
    description @title: 'Product Description';
    category    @title: 'Category';
    price       @title: 'Price';
    stock       @title: 'Stock Available';
    releaseDate @title: 'Release Date';
    isAvailable @title: 'Available';
};

 

After saving the file, restart the CAP server if needed and refresh the browser preview. 
The updated labels appear in the List Report.

You should now see readable labels instead of the original lowercase names, as shown in the above screenshot.  

 

2. Object Page Layout configuration (Details Page)

When any of the row item is selected from the table, we will be navigated to details page but there would be some error. You might see the Object Page fail to load with an error similar to: 

400 - Element "ID" does not contain a valid UUID 
 

This happens when the model uses: 

key ID : UUID;

 

but the CSV file contains values like: 

1,2,3,4 

 

Since UUIDs must be actual GUID strings, CAP rejects these when the Object Page tries to fetch a record by key. 

 

FIX

Update the CSV file to use valid UUID strings for each product, or change the key type to Integer. Most real CAP projects use UUID keys, so the CSV was updated to match. 

Replace the data sample of my.products-Products.csv with below data: 

ID,name,description,price,stock,category,releaseDate,isAvailable 
"B83D6B76-D790-4656-AFBB-79E2D1F0ABA6",Laptop,A powerful laptop for all your computing needs,1200.00,50,Electronics,2024-01-15,true 
"BEAA624C-8437-4D1D-B97C-3813BB73118D",Headphones,High-quality noise-cancelling headphones,250.00,150,Electronics,2024-02-20,true

After updating IDs: 

  • Restart cds watch 
  • Refresh the List Report 
  • Click a row to navigate to the Object Page 

Navigation should now work without errors. 

 

3. Resolving label, Facts and Field Group Issues 

 

While building the application, one of the simplest issues ended up taking the most time. The table columns and the Object Page labels were still showing in lower case and non of the Facets and FieldGroup annotation getting applied, even after adding annotations. It looked like a small thing, but it completely stopped the flow and took far longer to debug than expected. 

As shown below, the labels in the List Report and the Object Page simply refused to update: 

At first, the problem did not make sense. The annotations were correct, the service was running, and the UI preview was refreshing. But the labels stayed exactly the same. Eventually, the root cause turned out to be something very easy to overlook: the application generator had created an annotation file under the app folder, and that file was overriding the behavior. Since CDS annotations inside the UI module are not compiled by CAP, the UI was never getting the updated metadata. 

 

CDS-based annotations inside the app folder are not included in the service metadata, so the UI will never pick them up. 
Because of this, the generated file should be deleted or renamed to avoid confusion. 

 

There are two ways to manage annotations for the application: 

Option A (Recommended): Use server-side CDS annotations 

Move or copy all annotation blocks into: srv/annotations.cds 

CAP will compile these annotations and expose them in the OData $metadata. 
Fiori Elements reads its UI behavior from service metadata, so this is the cleanest and most reliable approach. 
This is the best practice for CAP-first projects. 

Option B: Keep UI-side annotation file and reference it from the UI 

If you prefer to keep the generator-created file under: app/productfe/annotations/ 

then the content must be translated into an OData annotation XML/JSON file and referenced directly in manifest.json as an annotation source. 
This keeps the annotations on the UI side only, and works independently of CAP metadata. 

This approach is possible, but it requires extra steps and is harder to maintain. It is usually not recommended when building applications with CAP, because UI annotations do not flow through the OData service metadata. 

 

Updated UI on deleting the annotation file following Option A 
 

Object Page Changes 

Updated Code Structure

using my.products as prod from '../db/schema'; 

// Element Level Labels 
annotate prod.Products with { 
    name        @title: 'Product Name'; 
    description @title: 'Product Description'; 
    category    @title: 'Category'; 
    price       @title: 'Price'; 
    stock       @title: 'Stock Available'; 
    releaseDate @title: 'Release Date'; 
    isAvailable @title: 'Available'; 
};

annotate prod.Products with @( 
    UI               : { 
        HeaderInfo     : { 
            TypeName      : 'Product', 
            TypeNamePlural: 'Products', 
            Title         : {Value: name} 
        }, 

        SelectionFields: [ 
            name, 
            category 
        ], 

        LineItem: [ 
            { Value: name }, 
            { Value: category }, 
            { Value: price }, 
            { Value: stock }, 
            { Value: isAvailable } 
        ], 

        Identification : [ 
            {Value: name}, 
            {Value: description}, 
            {Value: category} 
        ], 

        Facets: [ 
            { 
                $Type: 'UI.ReferenceFacet', 
                Label: 'Product Details', 
                Target: '@UI.Identification' 
            }, 
            {
                $Type: 'UI.ReferenceFacet', 
                Label: 'Stock Information', 
                Target: '@UI.FieldGroup#Stock'
            }
        ],
        FieldGroup #Stock: {
            Data: [
                { Value: stock },
                { Value: isAvailable }
            ] 
        },
    }
);

After applying this file and refreshing the preview, the Object Page should now have: 

  • Friendly labels 
  • A clean header 
  • Product details section 
  • Stock section 
  • Proper grouping of fields 

7. Summary 

At this stage, the Object Page now feels like a proper application screen rather than a raw auto-generated view. The fields have meaningful labels, the content is organized into sections, and navigation works without errors. These elements provide the structure needed for the next phase of enhancements as the application grows.

entry.title: SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf featured two hands-on sessions plus AI everywhere
entry.content:
SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf continued the momentum of the UX Foundation team showing the latest embedded AI features in My Home and the SAP Fiori elements framework. At our event on December 9, 2025, customers spent a day learning, developing, and networking with each other, SAP experts, and the sponsors.

Hands-on sessions showed how AI speeds application development

New for this iteration of SAP Fiori Innovation Day, we added an additional hands-on session beyond our usual one where people develop an SAP Fiori elements app using building blocks. The new one allowed people to try agentic app development with common AI clients and SAP’s MCP servers. This is a great way to save time creating SAP Fiori apps and an approach we are starting to use at SAP.

We also discussed the quality of AI-created code. Even if AI generates something faster than you could on your own, it is mandatory for you to understand the code so you can check it in with confidence and explain (or defend) anything during a code review. One of our architects explained that “I don’t know; the AI wrote this part” is not an acceptable answer. His main message was: “as a developer, you own the code.”

Graphic of the schedule for SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf

SAP Fiori continues to evolve to make SAP Cloud ERP easier to use

The day started with an overview of SAP Fiori and what this looks like in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. It included a discussion of the SAP Design System and how that includes common themes for UX consistency and enterprise product standards such as accessibility to help both designers and developers create applications that end users love.

Graphic showing overall strategy for SAP’s products

Demos illustrated and reinforced the points made in the slides. Similar to how you would begin your day with SAP Cloud ERP, we started with My Home and all the different ways you have to launch apps and make the page your own. The intro session also covered adjacent UX topics such as SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Start, and SAP’s mobile apps as well as a discussion of Joule and how it adds value across SAP’s portfolio.

Graphic showing Joule interaction patterns.

SAP Fiori includes more AI capabilities for business users

The afternoon demos were split into generally available and beta functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The released functionality included:

My Home

  • Card creation in My Home– creates cards that display essential business data that you can add to My Home
  • Joule-assisted insight card creation in My Home– ask Joule for the information you need and create a card that you can add to My Home
  • Recap – shows changes to tasks, cards, and app since you last accessed the system, making it easy to see what you missed when you were away

The recap feature in My Home shows you what changed in the system since your last access.

SAP Fiori elements apps

  • Easy filter – natural language searching in SAP Fiori elements list reports
  • Smart summarization – AI-created summary of SAP Fiori elements object pages
  • Error explanation – AI-assisted content that explains the meaning of error and provides suggestions on how to clear the error condition

Later in our “the future (one more thing)” session, we shared with some previews of planned AI functionality that will first be released into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Editon.

  • Easy Fill – copies text from an email or other source into the relevant fields on an object page
  • AI-assisted task automation (development code name “Smart Helpers”) – allows business users to automate steps in one or more SAP Fiori apps to streamline a complex process

Easy fill is currently in beta testing with selected public cloud customers. AI-assisted task automation is still in development.

The partners shared different ways to build the future you want in your SAP environment

The gold sponsors for SAP Fiori Innovation Day, eXXcellent solutions, cbs, and sovanta,  presented on topics that engaged the audience as each focused on solving a specific problem common to SAP ERP customers.

  • eXXcellent talked about how to add AI capabilities to your SAP system, even if you are running SAP S/4HANA on-prem.
  • cbs covered how to decrypt SAP error messages with AI, BTP, and a little magic from a tool they have created called ADAM.
  • sovanta discussed how to prioritize what apps to develop, since the cost of building apps is dropping significantly due to AI.

Thanks to everyone who made SAP Fiori Innovation Day a success

  • SAP Presenters (in order of appearance): Thomas Reiss, Katrin Polloczek, Ioannis Grammatikakis, Yeganeh Hajimiri, Katya Bondarenko, Marcel Kassner, Christoph Gollmick.
  • Gold sponsors eXXcellent solutions, cbs, and sovanta
  • Silver sponsors: Uniorg and STELACON
  • Behind the scenes team: all the developers, architects, product managers and other colleagues who built the features we showed, tested the systems, wrote the documentation, packaged the demos, and created the hands-on exercises.
  • Our executive sponsors: Alex Lingg, Ioannis Grammatikakis, Sebastian Steinhauer, Katja Zoch
  • Special thanks to Sebastian Werner and Conny Kinateder for all the logistics work that made everything run smoothly for the customers and partners.

Thanks to all the participants for their enthusiasm and great, probing questions throughout the event. Your feedback on what we showed helps us prioritize our development going forward. The conversations in the hallway, at the coffee machine, and during meals give us a deeper sense of where you are in your SAP Fiori adoption and how we can best serve your interests.

Next steps

  • Register for the monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable call to meet other developers and architects who build SAP Fiori apps.
  • Subscribe to the SAP Fiori development newsletter, in which we share updates on SAP Fiori elements, SAP Fiori tools, SAPUI5, and SAP Build Code every other month.  
  • Join us at an SAP Fiori Development Innovation Day in 2026 – we are looking at locations, dates, and some new event formats.

On behalf of the SAP UX Foundation Team, Peter Spielvogel.
